commentBody: Nice to see a pangram once in a while
I was just looking at my brother‚Äôs Apple Watch, which has an analog display for the time (and apparently, for the time being). I asked him about it, and he said he changes it as the mood hits him.
Kickstarter contributors are (at least in theory) backers rather than donors, GoFundMe would be a better choice for 52A

Nice puzzle and theme, but too many black squares. 

8/10

Post your time here
7:40 ‚Ä¶ pretty fast Tuesday

Orchard workers have apple watches.

(They've got great core processors.)
It was my last square, but DUSK for [Call it an early night?] is brilliant. Thanks for ending (for me) this Tuesday puzzle with a dose of wit and color!
Why is 1 across highlighted when viewing 58 down?

Wait a sec.  Smart watches don't have cases?  Of course they do.  Is the argument that the smart device in question isn't a smart watch but a phone app or a more exotic, minute little doodad?  Nope, not buying it.  I think this one was a poor answer, and it kind of ticks me off.  Relatively speaking.

It was otherwise a promising and timely theme.  :(

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
I didn't get 29 down or 53 across...what am I missing...
I got an absolutely kick out of the ‚ÄúCall after last Call?‚Äù clue, a very fun Tuesday puzzle

When you're retired it's hard enough to remember what day of the week it is without a Monday puzzle like this one.  You may think retirement is just one long vacation, but wait until you get there.  You'll wonder how you ever had time to go to work.

I'm not whining, I enjoyed the clues and preened at my fills, and there were no look-ups necessary, but it took me twice as long as a usual first day of the week puzzle. 

Greg, I am fascinated by your surname, but I will refrain from suggesting some tiresome clue (like "tiny tantrum"), and instead send you oceans of thanks, not only for your witty puzzle but also for the funny story about your WATCH parties.
This might be one of my favorite puzzles in a while. So many of the entries made me smile Thanks, Greg!

Once again, I was sure I was doomed to fail.

I had no idea what kind of JA__HANDS we were talking about.  I've never heard of DONEZO (I'm really suspicious about how common that is) nor could I figure out which of any number of silly words that ZONKING turned out to be.  Why not cONKING, or bONKING, or even wONKING, as with a policy debate.

This reads like a criticism of the puzzle, and it probably is.  I thought the double Natick was a little much, at least for me.

Nevertheless, I got a kick out of solving it.  And had I been stumped...I would have gotten over it.  I think.

Cute puzzle. Really liked the "Call it an early night?" clue. DRUNK DIAL reminded me of this song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3A1lV_Bl7ao Did not have any major problems with the puzzle, although I did have to wait for some crossings for a couple of answers, but they were fair and it all worked out.

Serves me right for doing the crossword in front of the TV (which drives my partner crazy anyway), but I filled in NUTCAKE so very confidently that it took me way too long to realize what the problem was. Finally saw that I had NAKA and now will put my phone away. (Sorry, sweetheart!) Fun little puzzle! Enjoyed DONEZO, JAZZHANDS, and ZONKED, which I very much am now. G‚Äônight!

Enjoyed a lot of clues (‚ÄúCall it an early night‚Äùand ‚ÄúCall after last call‚Äù in particular), but have one nit to pick as a representative of ‚Äò70s/‚Äò80s kids. 

ONEUP has nothing to do with a bonus life. 1UP in an arcade game simply meant that player 1 was playing.
When you leave a small tip it can also be a HINT that you didn't like the service. Double meaning here.

This was an enjoyable if easy puzzle overall, but I don‚Äôt think any of the theme answers match the revealer well, unless we‚Äôre *really* leaning into the ‚Äúmight claim‚Äù part:

CRYSTAL - Per the link from the column: ‚ÄúA watch crystal is the clear piece of material that protects the watch dial. The crystal might be made of glass, plastic or sapphire, depending on the watch.‚Äù Even if a smart watch doesn‚Äôt have an analog dial, the display and other internals (i.e., what‚Äôs in the smart watch‚Äôs CASE) are still protected by this sort of crystal‚Äîsome high-end smart watches even specifically use sapphire crystal displays. Additionally, virtually all digital computers, including smart watches, have internal clocks that are needed to keep the time for regulating the execution of instruction and other purposes. I looked it up, and these internal clocks usually use the same type of quartz crystal oscillators that are used in more traditional timepieces. (Plus, most smartwatches currently available use LCDs‚Äîliquid crystal displays‚Äîthough e-ink displays aren‚Äôt unheard of.)

DIAL - This one is a bit better, but as others have mentioned, many people set their smart watches to display a digital simulacrum of an analog dial, and some fancy smart watches do actually include analog dials, including physical HANDS and chronographs.

Again, none of this affected my ability to solve the puzzle, nor the overall quality of the fill, at all, but I can‚Äôt say this theme was particularly well thought out.
‚ÄúDonezo.‚Äù I‚Äôm out buh bye.
Really smooth and enjoyable, but I did have to think. Very nice!

I didn't manage this Tuesday puzzle. I doubted that cONKED (out) would be right for "totally beat," but I was pretty sure of the last five letters. I had (and still have) no idea what a gesture with "razzle-dazzle" might be. So I Revealed the next to last letter of a totally new and strange slang expression for "Finished." Oh, well. I had already had to look up "let me entertain you" to fill in G__SY, a musical I don't remember hearing about. (I don't remember very much anymore--I'm sure I must have heard of that one in my younger days.)

With both a Mario Kart reference, NOOB, and ONE UP in today‚Äôs puzzle, I wonder what our more senior co-enthusiasts, whom I figure are in the majority, think of these mechanics and terms. I imagine many of them solved NENA and GYSPY fairly easily. Actually, I imagine they have an easier time with the crossword in general, not because of answers from further back in history, but because of the wisdom that comes with having walked more miles. I hope those of them who haven‚Äôt tried out video games have sought to, if only out of intrigue over what it‚Äôs like to get pwned!

(As a ‚Äò90s chap I got all five without stress‚Ä¶ are we millennials blessed or cursed to have developed at the cusp of the digital age?)
Question for the group: I thought it was a rule that the clue and the answer have no words in common.  Is 1999 an exception just because it has numerals instead of words?

I've had an interesting experience with this puzzle. At first I thought it would defeat me: there seemed to be too many terms and proper nouns unfamiliar to me in either the clues or the answers. Whole quadrants of the grid were largely empty after my first pass.

Some of my unknowns: ESPN Deportes, a musical that premiered 21 years before I was born and thousands of kilometers away (my dislike of musicals in general did not help, either), ___ Mix. Also, I may be a gamer but I've never played anything from Nintendo (I'm a PC and Playstation person, and Atari before that) so I had no idea about STAR. I did not know ONE UP, either.

I thought I would need lookups or maybe even auto check to finish - which has happened on Tuesdays on occasion before. In the end though I managed to fill the grid relying on crosses and some creative guesses. My solve time was slightly long for this time in the week but not Wednesday-ish.

The theme actually helped me, for once. To protect my privacy I don't use any "smart" devices (and I have all personalisation and surveillance switched off on my phone), but knowing watch parts helped get me more letters for crosses.

Btw, Poland has been a tea-drinking country for some 200 years (coffee only became as popular as tea in the past few decades) so I'm quite passionate about my leafy brews. LIPTON makes really bad tea, nearly tasteless. Among the popular brands Dilmah is much better.

Warning: Possibly I‚Äôm just in a crotchety mood because I‚Äôve got Covid. And let me tell you, this whole ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not really ill or in pain till you‚Äôve lost a limb or have the bubonic plague‚Äù attitude Europeans have is the reason why the American expat community out here is so robust. Yes, we need people in our lives who fully understand why not having two well-stocked aisles of TheraFlu choices in the grocery store in order to self-medicate properly is like not having enough air to breathe. People who understand that the number of boxes and bottles of OTC flu-symptom relievers on our nightstand is inversely proportional to how serious our respiratory symptoms are. (I have lots of boxes and bottles here right now.) People who understand that when the doc tells us we‚Äôre not seriously ill, the uvular r in his ‚Äúserious‚Äù makes it sound like he‚Äôs mocking us. And what the heck is paracetamol? Why would any country not avail itself of Tylenol?

Oh yes, the puzzle. Well, I sped through it so clearly I‚Äôm not immune to pop culture, nor have I forgotten playing Mario Bros. as a kid in the 80s and wanting to look just like Meg Ryan. One thing occurred to me, though: Despite PTA being clued as [Scholastic book fair org], one could solve this entire grid having never read a single book. (No, the biblical clue doesn‚Äôt count.) The puzzle was fresh and spunky and such, but it left me with a feeling that we‚Äôre not a serious culture anymore. 

Maybe it‚Äôs just the Covid talking.

Apologies for being "that guy," but I feel a crossword puzzle, like journalism, should be representative of ALL knowledge and should avoid any subjectivity (whether you agree with it or not).  

It is a inherent necessity for crossword puzzles that knowledge be presented purely as observations or facts.

As such, I argue that the clue for "real man" should be affixed with "... for some".

(PS : I fully agree that wearing the ribbon is indeed a sign of a "real man".)

Tamal

Strands Thread:


Strands #359
‚ÄúLife is like a box of chocolates‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Please unwrap no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.


Sweet treat but over too soon.

Some very fun clues ("early night", "last call") in this sweet confection.  

Mr. Snitkin's debut (pronoun used confidently) a year ago also was inspired by interacting with his children (The Hokey Pokey).  Hope they continue to be his muse.  (Muses?)

Well done and thanks.

Well... that was different. Pretty typical Tuesday workout for me. Some fell together pretty smoothly; some I had to work a lot of crosses for things to dawn on me. And then... must confess that I wasn't entirely grasping the theme until I was done and went back and pondered for a bit. I guess I get it now. Puzzle find today - a very unusual one. A Sunday from October 13, 1991 by Ernst Theimer with the title "Implanted numbers." There were several rebuses in that and each was just a number: e.g. 11, 2, 0, 4. But the implication was for the answers to use the spelled out version of the number. A couple of examples: Customer group reveres : CLIENTELEVENERATES Which actually appeared as: CLIENT(11)ERATES And the down cross was: NOV(11)TS (NOVELEVENTS) "Faith ___!" (words by Faber) OFOURFATHERS which actually was entered as: O(4)FATHERS And the down cross was: BAL(4) (BALFOUR) "Some boxing preliminaries" LIGHTWEIGHTEVENTS which appeared as: LIGHTW(8)EVENTS and the down cross was: FR(8)AGE (FREIGHTAGE) And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=10/13/1991&g=113&d=A I'm done. ....
While playing "guess the revealer" today, I knew it was about a watch, but came up blank until I read the clue at 56 A.  It made this intentional Luddite laugh.

Not exactly a big fan of this puzzle... Clues and solutions were an odd mix of things I would never have known ("pwned"?? what is that??) and some that were super-easy (Musical from 1959 with "Let Me Entertain You"--Gypsy, right?)...So I just say "meh, bring on Wednesday's puzzle"--okay, folks?

Donezo, but not in record time. Some easy fill, lots of fun stuff, but then I lost steam in the lower half, so took a break, returned, and the new eyes saw all.

I haven‚Äôt worn a watch for years, but I remember them well. I have an aversion to wearing anything metal on my body. I don‚Äôt wear jewelry or watches at all nowadays except for cuff links and bolo ties.
Lipton? That is not tea! I like Indian tea, especially Assam, especially strong. I am a big tea and coffee drinker, tea for breakfast, coffee in the afternoon. I am very picky about both.

Truly appreciate the wit and whimsy
and just plain clever clueing.

Made it/feel like a Tuesday-level Friday!

Such fun!

Thank you Greg!

Sam: Yeah, one day there will be a new  parlor sport suitable for the vast population of couch potatoes. It will feature finding people at your party who can:
1. Tell the time when the clue is "The Big Hand points North, the little hand points East."
2. Draw the letters that go in each hole of a rotary dial telephone.
3. Use a pencil and paper to carry out long division, such as 6387/79.
4. Tell you what building on their college campus would have codes starting with "BF" or "QH" or "PN"?

Today's puzzle was good, but a little boring. I call it a "STEM WINDER' --(look it up, noobs!)

A good crossword for me, just a few bits of slang (DRUNK DIAL, DONEZO) and only a few of the usual cultural clashes; I didn't know Samuel Adams (guessed a type of beer) or CHEX. And a Mario Kart? No idea!
If anyone ever does a UK crossword, the marriage ceremony goes:
"Will you ...... take this man ..." 
"I will" 
No "I DOS."
I was surprised about the "REAL MAN' campaign, (unless it was from a long time ago?) Lots of business men wear pink shirts, lots of (male) professional football (soccer) teams wear pink strips, including the German national team, and pink football boots are quite common. Pink is on the way to losing its taboo, though not entirely. The wearing of coloured ribbons isn't common here any more, I haven't seen any for a long time.

‚ÄúWrinkle-free.‚Äù
Another sight from the before-times.
(Clothes too, not just the skin.)

Nice puzzle.

It‚Äôs going to be one of those weeks. This was crunchier than I‚Äôm used to for the early week fill. Still very enjoyable, like yesterday. Maybe I‚Äôm losing more brain cells.
The theme came slowly. I couldn‚Äôt remember the actor‚Äôs surname to start, but getting DRUNK DIAL lifted the fog. Of course, CRYSTAL.
Never played any video games (are they still called that?) so 1A unknown, but the crosses were easy. I adore Ms Amos. Was a little confused by 4D, but read in the comments it was to do with an, unknown to me, ad campaign. 
Press before MADAM held me up for a while, as did ALL RED. Obvious once I managed the crosses, but I stared at A‚Ä¶.D for ages with no clue.
Ah, the Amalfi coast. A memorable bus ride from Naples to Minori in a thunderstorm. Even through the heavy rain the scenery was spectacular, the driver insane! It felt like we were going to plunge off the unguarded cliff side at any moment. Thrilling.

I love the idea of a potty watch. Wish I‚Äôd been aware of the concept when going through it with my 3. Might have made life a little easier. Will be passing the concept on when grandkids start arriving.

Just remember we have 25D. to thank for inventing the "flo-thru" tea bag. That might come in handy in a puzzle on day.

I got tripped up with soccer powerhouse.

Cheers!
Loved!!! Easy, witty, and satisfying. The theme was fun and some of my favourite entries were DRUNKDIAL and DUSK. Thanks :)

I liked seeing: 
‚Ä¢	All those scrabbly letters in the grid.
‚Ä¢	Two EAR anagrams abutting LOBE.
‚Ä¢	That beautiful NYT puzzle debut NOT ON MY WATCH, and the clever double entendre on it.
‚Ä¢	Four palindromes, including a rare-in-crosswords quint (NUN, DVD, ASA, MADAM).
‚Ä¢	Beauty in the upper middle, with DEFT, BUOY, and ELUDE.
‚Ä¢	DONEZO!  I‚Äôve never heard of you before, donezo, but I‚Äôm smitten.

And I love the heartwarming fact that both of Greg‚Äôs NYT puzzles rose out of activities with his kids.

Crosswords as therapy.  I feel terrific after doing this.  Thank you, Greg!
Loved the clueing!

I confidently filled in DRiNK Down for 30A on the first pass, perhaps imagining that bartenders demand that drinks be downed (one way or another) after time is called the way proctors demand that pencils be downed after a test. I‚Äôve been in enough bars at closing time to know better, so it didn‚Äôt hold me up for long. It goes to show how test anxiety haunts our minds no matter how old we get, perhaps with a slight nudge from recently seeing Chumbawamba‚Äôs Tubthumping music video.

Thank you, Sam, for linking to the article about analog clocks. It was a wonderful essay and reader comments about how much easier an analog clock is to use vs. a digital one were very insightful (how much longer until? how long has it been? easy learning of fractions).

I guess this really IS "The Next Generation," at least in CrossWorld, because entries like DONEZO and ONE UP (as clued) and even ALL RED just seem peculiar and contrived... and what is 'ESPN Deportes,' pray tell? Sounds ominous.

I'm not even sure WATCHes have those particular parts nowadays.  

Disheartened by Captain Quahog's departure yesterday...but I guess it's one way to clear more time for other pursuits.  Like waiting to see what essential agencies get the axe next...

the obvious music link, 99 Luftballoons https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fpu5a0Bl8eY Ah, the times, they are a' changing. Used to be, you looked for someone wearing a watch if you needed to know the time. Now you look for someone with a phone in hand. Does anybody really know what time it is? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FzCWLOHUes Fun puzzle, Greg.
Fun solve but my mind just won‚Äôt let go that NENA is an artist or singer, not a band.

Never been a fan of digital watches. My kids got me a Timex Weekender when I retired eons ago. No alarms, no little day/date window. Just a trusty timeteller. Ill be wearing it when I'm too far gone to know what it is üòÅ

It's so interesting to read which clues stumped solvers! (Usually referring to rap and video games.) I remember when I started doing NYT puzzles in the early 1970s and the clues that stopped me cold had to do with opera and boxing. I guess boxing isn't as popular as it once was  - except for the occasional reference to Laila Ali. Opera has mostly dropped off the radar. Has anyone looked at the waxing and waning of certain topics over the years?
‚ÄúDonezo‚Äù shouldn‚Äôt be a thing. Let‚Äôs not encourage it.
Donezo? Really?

Why all of the breast cancer/"pinktober" clues? Are these just the puzzles that constructors hoped would be published in October? I never see clues about lung cancer or prostate cancer or colon cancer. Breast cancer is a very serious and deadly disease. Over 40,000 people in the United States die from breast cancer every year. If the NYT must disrupt my morning and my peace with these tasteless clues, can we at least make it about the survivors and thrivers and not the "real men" who wear pink?
DONEZO? That's what my subscription is going to be if they keep publishing this childish gobbledygook.

lol REAL MAN must've been confusing to younger solvers as we're so fortunate to live in a time when we've completely eradicated fragile masculinity




(Don't you pink?)

It was fun. Smiles for clues to 63A, 30A, 69A.  

Thank you for a good Tuesday puzzle.  

And I like donezo!
Fun fact: Sir Thomas LIPTON "competed for the America's Cup" five times over the course of thirty years, and lost every time. USA! So I was amused that those two entries abutted.
DONEZO? Really?

I, too, had never heard of DONEZO. I decided to look it up in Urban Dictionary and saw that the entry was created in 2004. So the term has been with us for over 20 years. Not a huge number of votes for it, though, with 387 on the first definition. Compare to, say "cray cray" with over 2700 votes. But still, I'd say it's a legit neologism for crossword purposes. ("Legit," btw, has just over 1,000 votes [and "btw" has over 5,000]).

Not sure why everyone is so mad at ‚Äúdonezo,‚Äù it‚Äôs emphasized as slang for a reason, and a decent amount of people say it. I almost immediately figured it out.

I personally was more confused at the phrasing of DUSK‚Äôs clue. Overall fun tho! :)

"donezo?"

Never heard it.
Donezo (which by the way was tough to get my iPhone to not autocorrect because of the obscurity) crossed with ‚Äújazz hands‚Äù is kind of unfair for early week‚Ä¶
Real man? Where?

Super fun puzzle.  Perfect for a Tuesday.  The throw backs to Nena and MarioKart were right in my wheelhouse.  Donezo was pretty easy to suss out and as a watch aficionado I totally enjoyed the theme.

I didn‚Äôt love the clue for ELUDE or the fill ALLRED. 

Fair bit of stuff that I got but is well outside the wheelhouse of somebody my age (NOOB, ‚Äúpwned‚Äù, DONEZO, ZONKED, ‚ÄúMario Kart‚Äù‚Ä¶). 

Overall fun puzzle though. Really liked the clue and answer for DRUNKDIAL.
How fitting that USA crosses with NUTCASE

Donezo: Have I ever used it? No. Have I ever heard it used? Not that I can recall. If I did hear someone use it, would I be able, from context, to figure out what it meant? Probably. Is it a "real word," valid to be a crossword entry? Who am I to argue otherwise? By filling in that entry, do I feel six squares less close to death, or at least cultural obsolescence? Yes, I do. Are there any other fans of the German Netflix series *Dark*? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oMHLkcc9I9c (The 1980's are so donezo!)
Apparently the ‚Äúavoid offensive language‚Äù rule doesn‚Äôt apply to the word G*PSY, was rather shocked when I got that answer from the crosses!
TIL Nena was a band, not just the name of the singer. All this time...

Wow. Lots of unfamiliarity with DONEZO.
FWIW, I‚Äôm a 71-year old retired librarian.üëµ
Wasn‚Äôt DONEZO uttered a couple of times in episodes of Stargate SG1?
Also: NOT ON MY WATCH.
Maybe today‚Äôs puzzle constructor, Greg Snitkin, was a fan of the show?
Loved most of the puzzle. But I got stuck on NOOB because I‚Äôve never heard of ‚Äúpwned.‚Äù Help!
Why is TORI the response to "Amos and Spelling"?
For the record, NENA was the stage name for Gabriele Susanne Kerner, and she stuck with it, but it was also the name of the band. Clearly it could be clued both ways. Pretty good puzzle today.

Hi, just fyi, the word gypsy is a slur for the romani people. It's used a lot in mainstream media but we need to stop! 

Love the puzzles as always!

Late puzzle find. By far the oddest one I've ever seen. Can't imagine that I would have any chance at solving this one. Anyway- A Sunday from June 16, 2013 by Mel Rosen with title: "Question box." 

Almost impossible to describe this one but I'll a stab at it. First - there were four long across answers (two 21 letter and two 18 letter) that were clued essentially the same. The first couple of examples: 

23a. Start of a trivia question : IFAGIRAFFEHASFOURTEEN

34a. Trivia question, part 2 : MORETHANAWALRUSAND

And the two were clued the same way with "Part 3" and "Part 4." Those answers:

94a.  ASQUIRRELHASHALFAS
107a. MANYASAPIGWHATARETHEY

And then... there was a 5 by 5 box in the middle of the puzzle, completely surrounded by black squares and there were no numbers on any of the squared in that box.and NO clues for any of the answers. But there was a Notepad with the puzzle that said: 
"When this puzzle is done, take the answers to the 10 starred clues and arrange them across and down in crossword fashion in the central 5x5 box. The resulting five-letter word spelled out diagonally by the circles will answer the question asked at 23-, 34-, 91- and 107-Across. "

Ran out of comment space. I'll continue this in a reply. 

...

I didn't love ‚ÄúLike many an ESPN Deportes watcher" = LATINO. It just seems a little bit lazy... why does it have to be a man who watches sports? Make it LATINA--or, if you need LATINO for DONOR across, make the clue something else that doesn't rely on the tired SPORTS = MAN stereotype. 

NYT Crosswords usually surprise me with their clever inclusivity, and this did the opposite.
This was lots of fun. Loved the theme. Thanks Greg. üòä

I loved this crossword! I confidently filled in JAZZHANDS with no crosses. Dunno. It just stuck out to me. 

And I knew NOOB (second time we've seen pwned in a matter of days!). And then I filled in DONEZO with only the Z and O. Was shocked at that one. My husband says it all the time but I don't think I've ever heard anyone else use it. Kinda thought he made it up. 

Everything else went pretty smooth except top middle because I spelled BUOY wrong. Transposed the U and O and it threw me off for a while.
A rare pangram today.  All 26 letters in the solution.
MAX airs John Oliver‚Äôs show, it‚Äôs no longer HBO, and hasn‚Äôt been for quite some time.

Fun puzzle with a nice challenge for a Tuesday, and the theme was especially fun.

I get a kick out of the wide range of attitudes and opinions here. We humans are quite the bunch.

My great grandfather was a silversmith who made tools for jewelers and my grandfather was a watchmaker and jeweler so I immediately picked up on the clues as I grew up with this terminology and used to visit my grandpa in his shop. Loved it!!
@Steve L Well, he made me look.

@Steve L I noticed. 

It's not important, obviously, but it's rare enough to be mildly interesting, and it had me wondering for a bit if it was intentional.
@Steve L I noticed too! Halfway through I started to suspect it and although JAZZHANDS was a gimme for me, it was made slightly easier because I was anticipating a Z (and got two!).
@Steve L I do, and it‚Äôs because the difficult letters are thrilling!
@Steve L Something must be done about Adam. Apparently he has an interest that you don‚Äôt share. The nerve of the guy.

@Steve L 

I prefer to use an analog face with extras (or complications, as Apple calls them), so I basically have 9 things I can do or start from there without using the side buttons, including looking to see what time it is. I've used the same watch face for a long time now.

@JayTee ‚Äúcomplications‚Äù is actually a term of art from the watch industry! Apple adopted it for their small watch-face widgets during initial product development :) 
(Source: my husband worked on the Apple Watch team for many years, starting when it was still a secret project).
@Joseph C Right, donor usually implies a gift without expectation of a return. Generally Kickstarter backers are essentially pre-ordering a product.

@Shrike I suppose the fact that some Kickstarter projects never see the light of production might mean that some backers never get anything in return, but you‚Äôre right - they donate with at least the hope of getting something.

@George 

That's the weirdest complaint I have ever seen, I think üòÆ
@Andrzej Reminds me of a scene in the movie Amadeus: "too many notes" said by by the patron to a frustrated Mozart.

@Andrzej 

It‚Äôs not as weird as it sounds. When you try to construct a puzzle, most construction software will tell you when your grid is unfillable (meaning that even with the yuckiest stuff in your wordlist, it can‚Äôt find words that work).

An easy ‚Äúsolution‚Äù to that problem is to start adding black squares (a/k/a blocks) because there are so many three- and four-letter words that it‚Äôs usually easier to fill a grid with them. 

But with that in mind: Today‚Äôs puzzle has 42 black squares, compared to an average of 37.4 for Tuesday NYT puzzles. When I first tried making puzzles, some experienced constructor advised trying to stay below 40 blocks.

@Andrzej

A more important statistic is usually number of words, which should be 72-78 for an early/midweek puzzle and ideally 72 or less for Friday or Saturday. Obviously you can pad the crossword with black squares especially in the corners to have smaller words so that is a consideration, but this seems very standard for an early week entry. Wondering if the commentator is pulling our leg a bit
@Andrzej I'm envisioning a crossword in which every square is black accept one. And the Clue is [A letter in English alphabet] That would be Celebrity NYT Crossword: https://tinyurl.com/y2mpcfd6

@Fabiano 

0:12... but that doesn't include any of the time I spent filling out the puzzle.  I just knew all the answers in 12 seconds. 

Honest.

Prove that I didn't.

@Fabiano

A while ago one of the columnists wrote about how the crossword is more about the solver vs the puzzle maker, not stuff like comparing times. I liked that sentiment.

@Fabiano 

Sorry about being such a wiseguy.

I'm amazed at your time, and I would be very proud to be anywhere close.

It might be similar for each of us to post how much you're bench pressing these days.

@Fabiano 
Let's just say that today's puzzle took my less than 1/4 of the time I spent on Monday's puzzle.  ü§≠

@Fabiano

@B 
Except that, if the apples are falling off the tree, they are rotten/rotting--on past ripe and no longer good for anything except (illegal) baiting for hunters...

@Mike
When Apple built their big round building in Cupertino as the new headquarters I thought they should call it the "Apple Core."  

I'm one of those old people who worked on computers that had core. Core was thousands of 1/16" little copper donuts.  One for each bit.  

In 1975 I worked for Four Phase Systems, just a block or two from the new Apple Core.  Four Phase made the first computers that had RAM instead of core!  Computer only the size of desk, instead of taking up a whole room!  It came in two models, with 96K or 128K of RAM.  And removeable hard drives that were about 16" across and 3" tall.

@Sue 

Surely you know that the Beatles had "Apple Corps" first, and I can't believe I didn't get the core / corps wordplay of that until just now.  :(

And the Wikipedia article says Paul wanted to call it Apple Core first!

I'm gen X/Millennial (born in 1980) and sometimes I feel like I'm too young to get clues about musicals, crooners etc. but at that same time too old for clues about the currently "in" things. Obviously where I'm from also plays a role (popular American culture from before the 80s is not my thing, because how could it be?), as does the fact my tastes seem to be idiosyncratic and slightly contrarian - I don't enjoy most modern series or films, I'm not on social media, etc. And even though I am a gamer with more spare time than you can possibly imagine for a guy in his 40s, I don't enjoy many of the most popular modern game genres - I wouldn't touch a battle royale or anything Souls-like or rogue-like.

@Alfredo I'm 71, but I did raise two boys in my own, and they' are both gamers, and I enjoyed watching them do that and occasionally played myself, so I know some of the intricacies of Grand Theft Auto, Monster Hunter, Unreal Tournament, StarCraft, World of Warcraft, etc.

@Eric Hougland 

I've had such different experiences with beer in different European countries they simply cannot be simplified like my tea conundrum.

There are places where you can always expect to find good, traditional beer at reasonable prices: Czechia, Germany, Austria. However, fancy US-style beers are often not readily available, sometimes for interesting reasons. E.g., in Germany a product may only legally be sold as beer if its ingredients are limited to water, malt, hops and yeast. Since IPAs and other US-style beers often have other ingredients, too, they may not be labeled as beer, which reduces their appeal.

Italy is not known for its beer, but actually, even the biggest Italian brands offer good quality and taste. One of my wife's and mine favorite Italian pastimes is to buy an extra large bottle of Birra Moretti from a street stall, sit down on a bench and drink slowly, enjoying Italian views and doing some people watching.

In France beer is good but very expensive - by glass (if not by volume) more expensive than wine.

In Belgium beers are malty rather than hoppy, and they are generally very strong, with the quadruppel offering wine-level alcohol content, but still sold in beer-sized portions. Delicious but risky.

@Sam Lyons. I hope you feel better soon. They do have flu medicine (at least here in Switzerland - Neocitran). Paracetamol and acetaminophen (in Tylenol) are the same thing. But I sympathize as I always came back from the US with lots of cold medicine. Somehow when you‚Äôre sick you want the stuff from home. Hope you get rid of the COVID quickly!

@Sam Lyons Oh, Covid is sneaky indeed. Just when you stop thinking of it ‚Äî whammo! And it can be downright nasty. I hope you‚Äôre going to make a quick recovery.

I LOLed at your uvular r comment. ü§£ü§£ü§£ You ain‚Äôt heard rs until you‚Äôve heard the Portuguese rr! The bemused looks I‚Äôve experienced as an immigrant to Europe (no plans to return to the USA)!

When I went for my first mammogram (fitting for 4D), the technicians were confused as to why I was asking for a paper robe. Doesn‚Äôt happen. Then, when I went for a GYN exam, the doctor remains in the room as you disrobe. She could not fathom my shame, especially given all that would occur next.  Oh, it‚Äôs different here!

Speedy recovery!

@Sam Lyons Ha ha! Yeah it's the Covid talking. That will get you in max curmudgeon mode. I can only assume that in general you find health care here to be a ton better than in the USA. I sure do. Getting the word paracetamol fixed in my head was a first step. One of my first steps on Day 1 of the Permanent Move ended with tripping and hurting my knee pretty badly, so paracetamol was needed! Plus 50‚Ç¨ for an urgent care visit (100% out of my pocket, so they apologized for the high cost). In the US that would have been $300? I hope you feel better soon. 

Pani, the nakedness in the doctor's office! "Just hold your shirt up to your chest and walk down this hallway." It's an adjustment. I assume you can identify the Americans in all medical offices, we're the bright red ones.

@Sam Lyons 

I just realized how un-American I was in my post - obviously I wish you all the best and hope you get well soon. Since it seemed obvious to me I did not spell it out, but that made my post look almost nasty compared to the others. I'm sorry about that. 

Covid can be a really nasty thing and I sympathize with you, truly. 

(This thread is a study in American-European cultural differences and my post was a case in point.)

@Nora 

Haha, we *are* the bright red ones!

I had an experience similar to you hurting your knee when I was on a trip out here some years ago. I had a stomach bug, passed out, and cracked a vertebra on my way down to the bathroom floor. Spent almost a week in a hospital. When I went to pay the bill at the end, the cashier hemmed and hawed, bright red like an American without a hospital gown. It turns out she was reluctant to hand me something as scandalously high as‚Ä¶ about $300. For a week in a hospital. With a broken back. 

There are downsides to socialized healthcare, to be sure, but the affordability is amazing.

@Andrzej 

No worries. I suspect it‚Äôs not always clear my tongue is firmly planted in my cheek 99% of the time.

@Sam Lyons 

Sorry to hear you have COVID. I hope you feel better soon and don‚Äôt suffer from any lingering effects.

@Nora Ha, ha!! This strange old world (to us) is one surprise after another. I‚Äôve read that being uncomfortable, trying new languages, customs and foods helps keep our brains sharp! 

As for the local folks knowing I‚Äôm American, it‚Äôs rare. I don‚Äôt turn red (I‚Äôm Black) and almost every person here assumes I‚Äôm from an African country. That‚Äôs even after I speak in my very American English üòÅ. One day soon I hope to be the first of my ancestors to step foot on the African continent for 400 years! @Tamal

That a REAL MAN wears pink is an opinion.
